title: Apparent Sudden Visual Loss: An Essential Approach
author: Colm McAlinden
keyPoints: Always consider giant cell arteritis as a cause of visual loss
Measure blood pressure in cases of suspected papilloedema
Always consider acanthamoeba keratitis in contact lens users
Sudden loss of vision is an ophthalmic emergency
redFlags: Giant cell arteritis symptoms (jaw claudication, temporal headache)
Central retinal artery occlusion (cherry red spot)

q1.text: Is the visual loss painful or painless?

q2.text: What type of pain is present?

q3.text: Are there signs of anterior uveitis or acute glaucoma?

answers.text: Acute glaucoma signs (hard eye, mid-dilated pupil)

q4.text: Is there a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD)?

q6.text: Any systemic symptoms suggesting GCA (age >50, ESR >50, temporal artery tenderness)?

q7.text: What pattern of visual field loss?

q8.text: Any flashing lights or curtain-like shadow?

gca_assessment.text: URGENT GCA ASSESSMENT: Check ESR, CRP immediately. If age >50 with typical symptoms, start prednisolone 80mg immediately. Urgent temporal artery biopsy within 7 days. Same-day ophthalmology referral.

gca_urgent.text: URGENT GCA: High-dose steroids (prednisolone 80mg or IV methylprednisolone). Urgent ESR, CRP, temporal artery biopsy. Immediate ophthalmology referral to prevent fellow eye involvement.

acanthamoeba_risk.text: ACANTHAMOEBA KERATITIS RISK: Contact lens wearer with pain and visual loss. Corneal scraping for culture. Stop contact lens wear. Urgent ophthalmology referral for specialist treatment.

acute_glaucoma.text: ACUTE ANGLE-CLOSURE GLAUCOMA: Immediate IOP lowering - topical timolol, brimonidine, pilocarpine. IV acetazolamide 500mg. Analgesia and antiemetics. Emergency ophthalmology referral.

uveitis_management.text: ANTERIOR UVEITIS: Topical steroids (prednisolone 1% hourly) and cycloplegics (cyclopentolate 1%). Same-day ophthalmology referral. Investigate underlying cause if recurrent.

crao.text: CENTRAL RETINAL ARTERY OCCLUSION: Immediate ocular massage, high-flow oxygen, IV acetazolamide. Check for embolic source (carotid doppler, echo, ESR). Urgent ophthalmology referral.

retrobulbar_neuritis.text: RETROBULBAR OPTIC NEURITIS: MRI brain and orbits with gadolinium. Consider multiple sclerosis workup. Urgent neurology and ophthalmology referral. May need IV steroids.

optic_neuropathy.text: OPTIC NEUROPATHY: Investigate cause - check B12, folate, thyroid function. MRI if compressive lesion suspected. Ophthalmology referral for further assessment.

other_optic_neuropathy.text: NON-ARTERITIC OPTIC NEUROPATHY: Check blood pressure, diabetes, sleep apnea. MRI to exclude compressive lesion. Ophthalmology follow-up for monitoring fellow eye.

macular_pathology.text: MACULAR PATHOLOGY: OCT macula, fluorescein angiography if indicated. Consider wet AMD, central serous retinopathy, macular hole. Urgent retinal referral if wet AMD suspected.

retinal_detachment.text: RETINAL DETACHMENT: Urgent vitreoretinal referral for same-day assessment. Position patient to keep detachment dependent. Emergency surgery may be required.

vascular_occlusion.text: RETINAL VASCULAR OCCLUSION: Branch or central retinal vein/artery occlusion. Check blood pressure, diabetes, cardiovascular risk factors. Urgent retinal referral.

glaucoma_assessment.text: GLAUCOMA ASSESSMENT: Check IOP, optic disc, visual fields. May be chronic glaucoma with acute presentation. Ophthalmology referral for glaucoma workup.
